title: Serious Fraud Office shuts down seven-year Libor probe
text:
The SFO launched a probe into Libor manipulation in 2012

The Serious Fraud Office is shutting down its seven-year investigation into the rigging of Libor interest rates – with just five bankers convicted.

The SFO launched a probe into Libor manipulation in 2012, after a scandal which has landed major banks with billions of pounds in fines.

Dozens of traders were accused of manipulating their institution's estimates to boost profits and bonuses.

The SFO's investigation, which has cost the taxpayer at least £60million, saw 13 individuals charged with conspiracy to defraud, and just five convicted.

Libor is the basic interest rate at which banks lend to each other.

It is calculated from estimates submitted by all the leading banks in London of what they would be charged if they borrowed from a peer.
description: The SFO launched a probe into Libor manipulation in 2012. Dozens of traders were accused of manipulating their institution's estimates to boost profits and bonuses.
